title: 106_s382
content: The Act titled "Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1999" is established for the purpose of preserving historical sites related to the Minuteman Missile. The Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missile launch control facility and launch facility known as "Delta 1" and "Delta 9" are recognized for their national significance as well-preserved examples of American history during the Cold War. These facilities symbolize the dedication and preparedness of Air Force missileers stationed in remote locations in the upper Great Plains. The Minuteman II missile defense system facilities in remote locations of the upper Great Plains during the Cold War are recognized for their historical significance. The purpose of this Act is to preserve and interpret these structures for future generations, as they represent the dedication and preparedness of Air Force missileers. The National Park System currently lacks a unit specifically commemorating the Cold War. The Act aims to preserve and interpret the Minuteman II missile defense system structures for future generations, highlighting their historical role in America's strategic commitment to world peace during the Cold War. It also complements the interpretive programs offered by the South Dakota Air and Space Museum at Ellsworth Air Force Base. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established to preserve and interpret the Minuteman II missile defense system structures from the Cold War era. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site in South Dakota is established as part of the National Park System, consisting of the Minuteman II ICBM launch control facilities. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site, established in South Dakota, includes the Delta 1 and Delta 9 Launch Control Facilities for Minuteman II ICBM. The map of the site is available for public inspection at National Park Service offices, and the Secretary of the Interior can make boundary adjustments. The Secretary of the Interior can make minor boundary adjustments to the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site, which is administered in accordance with relevant laws. The Secretary of the Interior can make minor boundary adjustments to the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site, in compliance with relevant laws applicable to the National Park System. The Secretary must consult with the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of State to ensure compliance with applicable treaties. The Secretary of the Interior can consult with the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of State to ensure compliance with treaties for the administration of the historic site. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with public and private entities for land acquisition within the site. The Secretary may acquire land within the historic site through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency, except for contaminated land. The Secretary may acquire land within the historic site through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency, except for contaminated land. The Secretary shall not acquire any land if contaminated with hazardous substances, unless all necessary remedial action has been taken. South Dakota land can only be acquired by donation or exchange. The Secretary may acquire South Dakota land by donation or exchange. Within 3 years, a general management plan for the historic site must be prepared, including evaluation of suitable locations for visitor and administrative facilities. The plan for the historic site must evaluate suitable locations for visitor and administrative facilities within designated study areas. Upon selection of a site, the historic site boundary will be modified to include the chosen location. The Secretary will modify the historic site boundary to include the selected location for visitor and administrative facilities. Coordination with Badlands National Park for administrative functions will be considered in the plan development. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out the Act, including transfer of Air Force funds for maintenance and operation of a historic site. No impact on Legacy Resource Management Program funds. The Secretary will use funds for establishing, operating, and maintaining the historic site. The Act does not affect funds for the Legacy Resource Management Program carried out by the Air Force for resource preservation and treaty compliance.
